propositions.text: The story begins with a paper boat.
The paper boat is made by Bill.
George chases the paper boat.
George dies shortly after chasing the boat.
It is 1957 in Derry, Maine.
The town has experienced significant flooding.
Power is out in most of the town.
The story jumps to 1984.
A character named Andra is mentioned as having died.
The police are investigating Andra's death.
George Denbrough's body is found, missing an arm.
The story jumps to 1985.
Stanley Uris is introduced.
Stanley is reading books by William Denbrough.
William Denbrough is referred to as 'Stuttering Bill'.
Stanley's wife, Patricia, finds the books disturbing.
Stanley Uris dies by suicide in a bathtub.
The suicide occurs on May 28, 1985.
Stanley Uris had a history of anxiety and recurring nightmares.
Rich Tozier receives a call from Mike Hanlon.
Mike Hanlon is calling Rich to come back to Derry.
Rich Tozier is a radio personality.
Rich Tozier recalls his childhood in Derry with his friends.
He remembers being bullied by older children like Henry Bowers.
The group of friends were known as the Losers' Club.
The story jumps to some time later in 1985.
Ben Hanscom is on a flight to Chicago from Omaha.
He appears to be drunk upon boarding.
He behaves politely and quietly once the plane takes off.
The flight is experiencing severe turbulence and lightning.
Ben Hanscom is identified as a passenger.
The flight attendant initially believes Ben Hanscom has died due to the conditions and his apparent state.
Ben Hanscom is alive and speaks to the flight attendant.
The narrative reflects on the ease with which life can be destroyed.
The Losers' Club was a group of children who were often bullied.
Members included Bill Denbrough, Ben Hanscom, Richie Tozier, Stanley Uris, Beverly Marsh, Eddie Kaspbrak, and Mike Hanlon.
They hid from bullies and shared traumatic experiences.
The story implies the existence of a malevolent entity in Derry.
This entity is associated with darkness and smells.
The entity is responsible for the deaths and misfortunes in Derry.
The paper boat is lost to the story after its journey through the sewers and rivers.
The story is titled 'It' (死光).

concepts.name: Paper boat
concepts.context: The paper boat is a significant object at the beginning of the story, used by George Denbrough and made by his brother Bill.

concepts.name: Derry
concepts.context: The primary setting of the novel, a town in Maine with a history of tragedy and supernatural occurrences.

concepts.name: George Denbrough
concepts.context: A young boy who dies early in the story, setting the stage for future events.

concepts.name: Bill Denbrough
concepts.context: George's older brother, known as 'Stuttering Bill', who becomes a writer and a central figure in the Losers' Club.

concepts.name: Flood
concepts.context: A significant event in Derry in 1957, highlighting the town's vulnerability and foreshadowing other dangers.

concepts.name: Stanley Uris
concepts.context: A member of the Losers' Club who dies by suicide in 1985, unable to cope with his anxieties.

concepts.name: Patricia Uris
concepts.context: Stanley Uris's wife, who experiences his decline and discovers his death.

concepts.name: William Denbrough's books
concepts.context: The novels written by Bill Denbrough, which are read by Stanley and are described as horrifying.

concepts.name: Mike Hanlon
concepts.context: A member of the Losers' Club and the historian/researcher of the group. He calls the others back to Derry.

concepts.name: Richie Tozier
concepts.context: A member of the Losers' Club, a radio personality who is called back to Derry by Mike.

concepts.name: Losers' Club
concepts.context: The group of childhood friends who band together to fight the evil entity in Derry.

concepts.name: Ben Hanscom
concepts.context: A member of the Losers' Club and an architect, who experiences a terrifying flight in 1985.

concepts.name: Entity
concepts.context: The primary antagonist, a malevolent supernatural force that preys on the children of Derry.

concepts.name: Death
concepts.context: A recurring theme throughout the document, with several characters experiencing violent or tragic deaths.

concepts.name: Memory
concepts.context: The act of remembering past traumas and events is crucial for the characters, especially in their return to Derry.

concepts.name: Fear
concepts.context: A pervasive emotion experienced by the characters, often driven by the supernatural entity and past traumas.

concepts.name: Suicide
concepts.context: The method of Stanley Uris's death, highlighting his internal struggles.

concepts.name: Calling
concepts.context: The act of communication via telephone, particularly Mike Hanlon's calls to the members of the Losers' Club.

concepts.name: Homecoming
concepts.context: The return of the adult Losers' Club members to Derry to confront the entity.

main_topics: The passage of time and return to Derry
The nature of the evil in Derry
hierarchy.structure: The document is structured as a narrative, divided into chapters or sections that jump forward in time. Each section often focuses on a particular character or event, contributing to the overarching story of Derry and its inhabitants. The structure uses chronological jumps to reveal plot points and character developments.
